review_blob:
The wax is always a pain.  It pours dark walnut brown with little  off white head and lots of haze.  The aroma is strongly of rasisin and figs, and as it warms lots of oaky coconut/vanilla aromas are present.  The first sip hits hard with strong alcohol, which quickly fades to strong notes of bourbon and figs, chocolate covered rasins with pralines. The second sip yields some maple syrup and cherries. The body is thick, rich and heavy.  The chocolate increases significantly as it warms up.  

All in all this beer is well worth the initial sticker shock, for layers upon layers of flavor for sure, it doesnt look very good at first pour but it makes up for it and then some.

I had the Lips of faith 2012 bomber bottle. Pours a brite clear ruby brown with low carbonation and little to no head.  Aromas of tart, caramel colored granny smith appels, with some vanilla oak and slight funk, very slight. The initial taste is strong sourness with plenty of caramel and dark toasted malt character balanced over the sour fruitness, some secondary hints of oak.  The palate has somewhat medium dense mouth feel and a long tangy sweet finish. 

Very good

Pours slightly turbid, almost clear golden straw with a rocky head that lasts (perhaps to effervescence).  Aroma only suggests tartness, mostly grassy citrus, close to lemon peel, followed by the reminiscent doughy, yeasty belgian wit aroma. Some subtle funk, barnyard on the nose too.  The taste is more tart than the armoa and spices come through strong, but not out of balance.  Soft "wonderbread" doughy malt in background, but present.  It is bubbly on the palate, with a quick and dry finish. 

It is too bad this is so expensive because it is a wonderful session "plus" : with just a bit more complexity than most wits but wonderfully drinkable. Drink this!

Strong aromas of sour aged lemons, horse blanket abound.  Loads of funk from start to finish, a bit too much to  keep it in balance. nicely tart but I get little passion from it.  all In all ok, the raspberry version is way better.
beer_name: Funky Buddha Passion Fruit Berliner Weisse

review_blob: This was great st hunahpu day ccb. Aroma is lots of pine and mint.  Body is juicy and resinous and flavor is top notch bitter dankness

Pours like dark matter.  Thick as motor oil with a burnt brown head.  The aroma is earthy and dark roast coffee, with a bit of soy sauce.  Flavor is bitter roast with lots of complex malt roastiness, the cedar gives great earthy, leather notes, too. Mouthfeel is just like it looks, sticky velvet that gets everywhere, in the best way possible.  This is damn good, drink some!
beer_name: Cigar City Humidor Series Imperial Stout

review_blob: Pours rusty orange, with slight haze.  Soft head that quickly fades.  Aroma is fruit and yeasty, with hints of tropical fruits, mostly pineapple, and a bit funky typical brett aromas.  The taste is crisp and lightly bitter, with lots of apricots and piney, earthy hop flavors.  There is a velvety, medium body.  Long fruity, funky finish.  Good beer

Im not a pumpkin beer fan anyway, but if Im going to drink one, Imperial it is!

This beer was rich and the complexity was so high it is hard to get the pumpkin at first.  So many spices it takes several gulps to go through them all.  Good Autumn beer! drink up!
beer_name: Cigar City Good Gourd Imperial Pumpkin Ale

review_blob: This is a funky one.  Aroma is figs and peppery, yeasty spice.  The body is a bit thinner than I would expect (more like Saison than Scotch ale).  Plum and raisins mixed with lots of cloves on the palate.

Nice copper peach colored pour with a head that fizzled quick.  Awesome aroma amazingly similar to Sauvignon Blanc with tart pears and apricots hit with some grainy doughy malt and of course guava!  Thick body, Tart but not overly so with strong flavor of Guava (duh!).  Definite yeast earthiness but very pleasant Moderately dry finish with that lingering tart zing!  It is refreshing but not light.  

I had Grove a while ago but the Groove is something to try!

Had this at the tasting room 3/18/2011.  Pours like oil, and has a caramel head that falls quick.  Amazing complexity with a strong cocoa flavor initially that gives way to the heat of the peppers as the beer warms up.  It sits on you tongue as heavy as one would expect an Imperial stout.

  Overall well worth all the hype and cost, but if you have one of the 750 bottles, make sure you have some very special friends to enjoy it because one pint is a but much, and I would definitely use some snifter/tulips.
